29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
Roy Lupton has got a limp. A limp what you

34.text:
may ask. But still he is out after roe deer.
We have got politics for you. The future of

39.text:
lead shot in the UK. In News Stump, we have
a big fox weighing 34lb from Russia. This

45.text: photograph was sent in by viewer Vinnie Jones.

49.text:
But first children, dogs, rabbits, we must
be out ferreting.

56.text:
We've filmed the South Somerset Ferreters
before. Well, they're back - and this time

60.text:
they reckon they've got the ultimate warren.
It's a hill not far from the South Devon coast

66.text: and it's a honeycomb of buries.

69.text:
The South Somerset Ferreters are a group of
families who get together on a Saturday not

72.text:
to go shopping, not to go to a theme park.
They go ferreting.

78.text:
Between them, they have everything that ferreters
need, including two lurchers, a little Lakeland/whippet

82.text:
cross and their not-so-secret weapon, Louis,
a remarkably sprightly 10-year-old Jack Russell.

89.text:
Also on hand to help is the Fieldsports Channel
cocker spaniel Muffin and her year-old daughter

95.text:
Yes, I don't think it really gets any better
than where we are today, anywhere in the country

101.text:
First job is to put the nets out - both long
nets and purse nets

105.text:
We know what we are up against today, because
we did it last year. Yes like I said we have

111.text:
got the whole perimeter again. Blocked off
the long nets and we have still got a lot

117.text:
of purse nets to set. Roughly about 200 nets.
Yes it takes time, but if you don't put the

125.text: time in, you don't get the rewards.

128.text:
It's not just a case of bunging a net over
a hole and banging it in.

133.text: So you have got different sized nets here?

136.text:
Yes, I have got four footers, five footers
and six footers, all for different holes.

139.text: Does it depend on the size of the hole.

144.text: Then there are the elastic bands

148.text:
Every purse net we use, we put an elastic
band around. So when we pick them up if we

154.text:
have any elastic bands left we know we are
missing a net from somewhere.

159.text:
It takes a couple of hours to put out this
many nets.

162.text:
About 600 yards of long net we have got to
set up around as well, five dogs, about 15

169.text:
ferrets which we put down all in one go. So
hopefully fingers crossed, not a lot will

175.text:
Next up the stars of the show. The ferrets.
We take time off for a bite to eat. Then - nets,

182.text:
dogs, children - everyone gets in position.
There's even time to disentangle Mina from

191.text:
The first rabbits don't take long to bolt.
Men, women and children are stationed round

196.text:
the long nets, ready to dive on anything that
wriggles.

199.text:
After a quarter of an hour of no activity,
we reckon we have had the best of this bury.

204.text: Now we have to retrieve the ferrets.

207.text:
When ferrets lie up and have to be dug out,
they uncannily choose the thickest part of

212.text:
the brambles. You need to sweep the brambles
with Ferret Finders.

216.text:
Just goes to show that without these finders
you would lose ferrets. He went right the

221.text:
way across the other side. So good we have
got them all back now. Plus a rabbit for a

231.text:
Years of experience tells them that this last
ferret is deep underground. The fastest way

235.text:
to cut through the bramble roots is to send
in Louis - still keen as a puppy. Once Louis

241.text:
has done his work, Jaf calls for another piece
of kit. It's a ferreting endoscope.

248.text:
At last we find the final ferret. It was nowhere
near the brambles but in the next field, curled

258.text:
The next step is the main event. We're ferreting
the open hillside. Jaf is relieved to find

264.text:
the bury here is not connected to the holes
under the brambles next to it.

268.text:
We get more rabbit action from this side of
the hill - and we're in a perfect place to

274.text:
There is even an opportunity to train a young
dog to stay away from ferrets.

279.text:
The last ferret of the day has chosen the
only clump of gorse to lie up beneath. It's

284.text:
another digging exercise, with Louis on hand
to offer help.

288.text:
If you want to find out more, search for South
Somerset Ferreters on Facebook. And if you

292.text:
want to see our last film with them, click
on the link on the screen. Or why not make

296.text:
your Louis very happy and start your own ferreting
group.

300.text:
Well it is time for the South Somerset Ferreters
to break for lunch and it is time for you

304.text: to watch David on the Fieldsports News Stump.

319.text:
We recently produced a programme called the
Ferrari Macnab. Now exprofessional footballer

324.text:
and Hollywood A-lister Vinnie Jones has sent
us a new one: the Macnabski. On a filming

331.text:
trip to Russia, Vinnie took time off to shoot
a fox and a raccoon and caught a salmon in

336.text:
one day, then went on to rope an 800-pound
bull. After he tried hard with a fly, the

343.text:
salmon fell to a spinner. The fox weighed
in at a remarkable 34 pounds without the snow.

349.text:
They make them big in Russia - but the British
record is 36 pounds. It was a 212-yard shot

358.text:
Two shooters from north Yorkshire raced to
the rescue when a light aircraft crashed in

363.text:
front of them. DTL shooter Jack Thompson,
who won the BASC World .410 Championships

368.text:
in September and his mate Sam Graham were
about to start pigeon shooting when they witnessed

374.text:
the crash. They dashed across the field in
their four-by-four, crossed a dyke and climbed

377.text:
a bank, to find the two pilots dazed but unharmed.
It is thought the Piper Arrow aircraft had

383.text:
suffered engine failure. Jack and Sam helped
to ferry emergency services personnel and

387.text:
firefighting equipment to and from the scene
before abandoning their shooting plans.

394.text:
The best retrievers and handlers in Britain
and Ireland are heading for the Cawdor Estate

399.text:
in Northern Scotland next week. Some 55 dogs
are expected at the 2012 Retriever Championship

406.text:
will be held from 26th to 28th November 2012.
International Gundog League sponsor Skinners,

412.text:
which also sponsors this news bulletin, is
delighted to have been associated with the

416.text:
IGL for nearly 30 years. For more info, go
to www.InternationalGundogLeagueRetrieverSociety.org.uk

425.text:
Now do you fancy high pheasant shooting for
a quarter of the price of Devon or Northumberland?

432.text:
That dot in the sky is a pheasant. We are
now panning down to the shooter. Sporting

436.text:
agent Lasarotta which specialises in sport
in Croatia and Serbia is offering two back-to-back

442.text:
300-bird days in December at £13 per bird
plus flights. Visit www.lasarotta.co.uk

450.text:
Cartridge company Gamebore is backing two
new clay competitions in 2013. Based on the

457.text:
popular White Gold Cup, one new competition
is called the White Gold Challenge. Gamebore

462.text:
also plans to run a championship called the
Gamebore Gold Cup, a 150-bird Sporting course

467.text:
at the Westfield Shooting Ground in Gloucestershire.
Visit Gamebore.com for more.

472.text:
A retired policeman from Germany spent three
hours to try and land a 540-pound halibut,

479.text:
a new world record. The fish was so big that
at one point Reinhard Wuhrmann's rod snapped

485.text:
in two. The 62-year-old with two others, fishing
off Norway, others were only able to haul

489.text:
it onto their boat after tying a rope around
it when it came alongside. The previous record

494.text:
for an Atlantic halibut was held by fellow
German Gunther Hansel who caught a 483lb specimen

504.text:
And finally another story about shooters saving
the day. This time we are in South Dakota,

509.text:
USA. A party of pheasant shooters discovered
two deer with antlers locked together. One

514.text:
deer had already died and the eagles were
feeding on it as the other one struggled to

518.text:
get free. The shooters estimated that these
deer had been in this situation for at least

525.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

536.text:
Now from Hollywood stars to the Fieldsports
Channel A list. It is Roy Lupton.

544.text:
Now it may appear to regular viewers that
Roy hasn't been quite so eager to pull the

549.text:
trigger of late. A few opportunities during
the roe and fallow rut have presented themselves,

554.text:
but Roy has fought temptation in the name
of deer management. All good things come to

561.text:
A bit of will power means a deer that looks
good one year can mean medal quality the next.

567.text:
Well that's all very well and good in theory
but then someone comes along and screws it

572.text:
all up. And more often than not these days
it's poachers. Roy has got a few of those

578.text:
making their presence felt on his ground in
Hampshire.

581.text:
Now unfortunately we have got a big problem
which is emerging throughout most of the country,

588.text:
and that is commercial poaching. Unfortunately
this old boy here has been a victim of it,

595.text:
but the biggest problem we are facing is it
is not just one or two individual animals

599.text:
which are being taken. We are now looking
at poaching on a commercial scale. So it is

605.text:
not your romantic view of a poacher going
out and getting one for the pot, it is organised

610.text:
groups of individuals going out with illegal
fire arms shooting deer, or taking deer with

616.text:
dogs and that is having a massive effect on
the population and a massive effect on the

621.text:
deer management. Up until now a lot of the
police forces have been treating this with

627.text:
a little bit of apathy. My hope is that by
working together with stalkers, estates and

633.text:
the local wildlife liaison officers that we
can put an end to commercial poaching. And

638.text:
hopefully put an end to seeing sights like
this and finding poor old beasts left in the

644.text:
With that off his chest Roy turns his attention
to the evenings stalking. He is here for roe

650.text:
does which are really only evident at last
light.

652.text:
We have got about an hour and a half before
it is dark completely, so we are going to

656.text:
have a quick scurf around to see what we can
come up with. There are couple of does that

661.text:
I don't really want to take out. We have got
a doe just down, which has been working the

665.text:
piece of ground to the left hand side and
she had triplets this year so it would be

669.text:
nice to leave her on . So we are either going
to look for a yearling doe or maybe somebody

676.text:
With his recovery from his hip op going well
he's now down to just one crutch plus shooting

681.text:
sticks - which we think gives him a look of
Gandalf.

686.text:
Our first port of call is a wood which always
delivers. Nowt. It is weird how some places

693.text:
just feel right for deer but for some reason
it's a desert - certainly in our case.

698.text:
Never mind. It's a beautiful evening - perfect
for a stroll in the British countryside. With

704.text:
the pheasant and partridge shooting season
in full swing the deer are a little more cautious

709.text:
which makes this stalking more of an educated
guess than normal.

712.text:
We are just going to have a quick run around,
try and find the hot spots and try and get

717.text:
into position when the does start feeding
out from some of the cover crops and some

720.text:
of the woods. It is always a gamble. You have
just got to pick a spot and hope.

728.text:
We keep watching, we keep stalking, but there
is nothing about. This is a Roy stalking outing.

734.text: Apparently failure is not an option.

737.text:
I can see the sun is starting to dip behind
the trees and we have got a rather eager cameraman

741.text:
to highlight the start of the doe stalking
season and so far we haven't seen a deer.

750.text:
So this is the panic stage. And from the panic
stage you hope you can up with some concoction

756.text:
to get on to a deer, but if they are not out,
there is not much you can do.

763.text:
We lose the light and the chance of a deer.
Roy does spot one with the superior glass

768.text:
on top of his rifle but we lose her in the
cover crop.

772.text:
Of course there's a host of reasons why we
blanked - but Roy can't help feeling it's

778.text:
We have been beaten by the light, but the
odd thing is though, normally on this estate

783.text:
on an evening's stalking you will easily see
20 may be 30 deer just on the little route

789.text:
we followed and this evening we have had perfect
conditions for it. It has been a nice relatively

794.text:
warm evening, the wind wasn't too hard or
too cold. You just couldn't want for better

798.text:
conditions and yet we didn't see a single
beast and I think unfortunately we are seeing

805.text:
the results of a lot of poaching going on,
not just on this estate, but in the surrounding

809.text:
areas. We will come out in a couple of evening's
time and see if we can find a roe for the

814.text:
freezer, but at the moment it is certainly
not looking good.

818.text:
Not to be beaten Gandalf keeps to his word
and without any help from a camera man nor

823.text:
stalking buddy heads off to try and shoot
and film some roe. This time he's on the other

829.text:
side of the estate which hasn't been targeted
by poachers.

833.text:
Roy chances upon a roe doe lying up on a ride
about 90 yards away. It was just a flick of

839.text:
the ear that gave her away, otherwise she
would have gone unseen.

842.text:
We have got a doe and a kid just couched up
along the ride. Now what I want to do is just

854.text:
wait and hopefully one of them will stand
up and hopefully give us an opportunity of

859.text:
a shot. The only problem is that can very
often happen if you are waiting for a deer

864.text:
to stand they can stand up and turn off carry
on away from you and disappear. That is the

869.text: chance we will have to take.

871.text:
Roy's patience pays off and eventually the
doe stands up. He shoots and she drops in

876.text:
the cover crop. She isn't alone. Roy repositions
and takes the kid as well. It's probably not

883.text:
dependent but Roy feels it's the best thing
to do with winter on its way.

888.text:
We have caught up with where the doe is she
was just on about 90 yards from where she

895.text:
was shot she has probably gone 2 or 3 yards
just into the thick, heavy cover there. No

900.text:
problems finding her and obviously the kid
just dropped on the spot further down the

905.text:
cut out in the game cover strip here. Nice
successful evening now it is to drag them

911.text:
out and sort out the gralliching and we can
go home and have a nice cup of tea.

916.text:
So a good result and a grand effort by Roy
who managed to shoot two deer, capture it

921.text:
on film having stalked into them while carrying
a video camera plus tripod, a set of shooting

926.text:
sticks, a crutch, a pair of binos and a rifle.
Maybe he does have magical powers after all.

933.text:
Last week a conference in London examined
lead shot. Does it have a future. We went

947.text:
Dying dolphins, poisoned eagles, foolish foxes
and the grey partridge in crisis - it was

953.text:
not the most upbeat symposium ever held. The
most controversial presentation came from

959.text:
Bjorn Beckmann of an academic body called
the Centre for Ecology & Hydrology. His talk

965.text:
on sea eagles and the threat from lead poisoning
claims that lead from bullets and from shot

971.text:
is the single biggest killer of sea eagles
in Germany.

975.text:
So out of these eagle's carcasses that have
been studied, 34 were found to have had lead

986.text:
particles in the stomach and out of those
80% were lead core bullet fragments and six

995.text:
lead shot. Unlike, I think, the common perception
at least in the case of sea eagles, the lead

1005.text:
core bullet fragments are the major problem
not lead shot. It is also a problem, but this

1015.text:
Members of the symposium audience pointed
out the recent article in Shooting Times magazine

1020.text:
that defends lead shot. However, a representative
of the Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust poured scorn

1027.text:
In other presentations, Nick Sotherton of
the Game & Wildlife Conservation Trust talked

1032.text:
about the grey partridge, the iconic bird
that is the symbol of the GWCT

1036.text:
I have been asked to try and produce some
good news. I am not sure I can. Species of

1047.text:
British breeding farmland bird that has undergone
unprecedented declines over the last 30 to

1056.text:
40 years. And you can see 90% decline through
that time period. It is a biodiversity action

1060.text:
plan species, it is red listed under the birds
of conservation concern. You name it every

1067.text:
Jim Barrington, speaking on behalf of the
day's host, the Veterinary Association for

1072.text:
Wildlife Management, slammed the disneyfication
of our wild animals. With this slide, he showed

1078.text:
how animal brains cannot project forward like
humans can.

1082.text:
That area of the brain which collects and
assesses and looks after information is simply

1089.text:
not there. There is no way in which animals
of say the fox level or the deer level can

1095.text:
project ahead and so this is quite important
as far as its mental abilities are concerned

1102.text:
and of course when people say, you wouldn't
like it would you? Well of course not because

1106.text:
we are humans. We are not animals at that
level.

1110.text:
Jim is former head of the League Against Cruel
Sports but resigned when he realised how hunting

1116.text:
benefits the fox. He is now a consultant to
the Countryside Alliance.

1121.text:
Excitement came from London Zoo, which is
studying whale strandings. Rob Deaville presented

1126.text:
a film showing bottlenose dolphins off the
British coast beating up porpoises.

1132.text:
This is shot in the Morray Firth and you can
see a porpoise being hit out of the water

1136.text:
by three bottlenose dolphins and again in
slow motion here. Quite a size disparity between

1145.text:
these two species. The bottlenose we have
in the UK are huge compared to Flippa on the

1150.text:
If you are watching this on YouTube and you
want to watch the whole of the symposium,

1154.text:
seven-and-a-half hours long, click on the
link on the screen.

1158.text: Next it is our Bushcraft hero Jonny Crockett.

1166.text:
There is nothing quite as cheery as a fire.
It is essential for cooking. Here is how to

1177.text:
build one properly and get it going without
matches. We will need tinder to get the fire

1182.text:
going. Two good resources for this are dry
goose grass and dry bracken.

1187.text:
So I have got some goose grass here to make
the heart of my tinder bundle. Now I just

1191.text:
want something to bulk it out a bit. I have
got some nice dead bracken here and this bracken

1197.text:
will sit round the back of it. Got a bit more
here. I don't need a huge amount, but this

1205.text:
will just provide that extra flame just to
get the tinder going. You need to be a bit

1211.text: careful when pulling on bracken, it can cut.

1216.text:
For the larger kindling we need dead wood
and that needs to be collected. Fallen branches

1222.text:
are the best source for this. They can often
be found caught up in holly bushes.

1228.text:
So this nice fine wood that is what is going
to catch first and so we put this on a separate

1237.text:
pile. You can afford to be a little bit obsessive,
compulsive about this if you want. The more

1244.text:
organised the better your preparation, the
better chance you have of getting your fire

1252.text:
With the fire wood gathered it is time for
the magic to commence. Here is how to use

1255.text:
a flint and steel to light your fire. What
I am going to do is just flick down and make

1264.text:
sparks and those sparks are coming off the
soft metal here. I have got a nice hard piece

1270.text:
of flint and when I strike down, you see all
the sparks are going up. So if I put a bit

1280.text:
of amadoo, if I put that on the top and then
strike down, the shards, the hot bits of steel

1292.text:
will come up and fall down on the top - aha
first time.

1301.text:
You can see now how that works. We can put
that inside our tinder bundle ...........and

1330.text:
that goes down onto our raft and then our
two bundles of sticks, one goes on the top.

1356.text:
Now once this has started to burn then we
can go onto the bigger stuff which is the

1363.text:
proper full on fuel wood and that is what
we are going to be cooking on later on.

1368.text:
Well Jonny's DVD about survival will be available
very soon. Keep watching this programme. Now

1375.text: onto the wilder world. It's Hunting YouTube.

1378.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1383.text:
Hunting FPS has not being doing much on YouTube
recently which is a great shame - but he did

1387.text:
manage a couple of trips recently when the
sun was out, and here is the footage. As you

1391.text:
can see from Slow Motion Airgun Rabbit Hunting
#18, the bunnies have been causing a bit of

1395.text:
damage and the farmer is keen for their numbers
to be reduced.

1398.text:
Now the clay season is not at its height in
the UK at the moment on account of the wintry

1403.text:
weather but here's a good idea. AntiguaClays
is the YouTube channel for a shooting resort

1408.text:
in the Caribbean, which claims to be the only
one of its kind. Even if you can't afford

1412.text:
the air fare, here's a film to lighten up
your day.

1415.text:
The Lagotto Romagnolo is one of the new breed
of gundogs that follows in the pawprints of

1419.text:
such Italian masterpieces as the spinone and
bracco. The famous gundog photographer has

1423.text:
a YouTube site. NickRidley9261's film shows
a group of UK based Lagottos demonstrating

1428.text:
their traditional work as gundogs. From the
Romagna sub-region of Italy. The name means

1435.text:
Now on to fish. Monster lake trout, world
record laker is a rediscovered film, thought

1440.text:
to be lost, dating from as long ago as 1996,
when Bob Mehsikomer caught and released a

1446.text: possible 60-pounder on Lake Athabasca in Saskatchewan.

1450.text:
Moving Down Under, Fishing Exmouth with bream
gear and MadEye lures is Aussie Breamer's

1455.text:
latest technique for one of Australia's favourite
sea fish. This film took a week to make.

1459.text:
With Christmas coming, the DVD makers are
using YouTube for their trailers - and it

1463.text:
looks like wild boar is top of the list. Here
is trailer to the hunting DVD Baiting Wild

1468.text:
Boar, made in Sweden and with lots of shooting
action.

1471.text:
From Russia, Sladkova is a trailer for a DVD
about hunting for wild boar, roe deer, red

1476.text:
deer and game birds. More bucks, more boar,
more bangs.

1479.text:
And from Spain, Reivax Films presents Great
Hungarian Hunts. Once again, it is driven

1484.text:
wild boar that are face the cazadores. There
three films and four countries. All of these

1489.text:
films lead you to websites where you can purchase
DVDs.

1492.text:
And don't forget the fabulous DVD's on offer
on the Fieldsports Channel website www.fieldsportschannel.tv

1498.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch

like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,

Well we are back next week. If you are watching

and watch just this show and not all our other
